a.g: Exalted is He who took His Servant by night from al-Masjid al-Haram to al-Masjid al-Aqsa, whose surroundings We have blessed, to show him of Our signs. Indeed, He is the Hearing, the Seeing.
And We gave Moses the Scripture and made it a guidance for the Children of Israel that you not take other than Me as Disposer of affairs,
O descendants of those We carried [in the ship] with Noah. Indeed, he was a grateful servant.
And We conveyed to the Children of Israel in the Scripture that, "You will surely cause corruption on the earth twice, and you will surely reach [a degree of] great haughtiness.
So when the [time of] promise came for the first of them, We sent against you servants of Ours - those of great military might, and they probed [even] into the homes, and it was a promise fulfilled.
Then We gave back to you a return victory over them. And We reinforced you with wealth and sons and made you more numerous in manpower

[And said], "If you do good, you do good for yourselves; and if you do evil, [you do it] to yourselves." Then when the final promise came, [We sent your enemies] to sadden your faces and to enter the temple in Jerusalem, as they entered it the first time, and to destroy what they had taken over with [total] destruction.

[Then Allah said], "It is expected, [if you repent], that your Lord will have mercy upon you. But if you return [to sin], We will return [to punishment]. And We have made Hell, for the disbelievers, a prison-bed."
Indeed, this Qur'an guides to that which is most suitable and gives good tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that they will have a great reward.
And that those who do not believe in the Hereafter - We have prepared for them a painful punishment.
And man supplicates for evil as he supplicates for good, and man is ever hasty.

And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Haste is from Satan, and deliberation is from God, the Exalted." And the Almighty has said: "Man was created from haste [min 'ajalin]." And He, the Exalted, has said: "And man is ever hasty [â€˜ajÅ«lan]." This is because actions [al-a'mal] should be after insight [al-tabá¹£irah] and knowledge [al-ma'rifah], and insight requires contemplation [ta'ammul] and deliberation [tamahhul], and haste prevents that. And during haste, Satan promotes his evil upon man from where he does not perceive.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Do not think that the purpose of the sun and moon moving in a precise, ordered calculation, and the creation of shadow and light and stars, is to be aided by them in worldly matters. Rather, it is to know by them the measures of times so that you may occupy yourself in them with acts of obedience (Taa'aat) and trade for the Abode of the Hereafter (Al-Daar Al-Aakhirah). This is indicated to you by His saying, the Exalted: 'And He is the One who made the night and the day successive for whoever desires to remember (Yadhkur) or desires to be grateful (Shakooran).' {} Meaning, one of them succeeds the other so that what was missed in one may be made up in the other, and He clarified that this is for remembrance (Dhikr) and gratitude (Shukr) only, and nothing else. And He said, the Exalted: 'And We made the night and the day two signs (Aayatayn). Then We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day seeing (Mubsiratan), that you may seek bounty (Fadlan) from your Lord and that you may know the number of years and the calculation (Al-Hisab).' {} And indeed, the bounty (Al-Fadl) sought is the reward (Al-Thawaab) and forgiveness (Al-Maghfirah), and we ask Allah for good success in what pleases Him.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Indeed, Allah has made the night and the day two signs [ayatayn], so He effaced the sign of the night and made the sign of the day seeing, that you may seek bounty [fadl] from your Lord and that you may know the number of years and the calculation. And the bounty sought is the reward [thawab] and the forgiveness [maghfirah], for the purpose of the sun and the moon running by a precise, ordered calculation, and of the creation of the shadow and the light and the stars, is not merely to seek help through them in the affairs of the world [dunya], but rather that you may know by them the measures of the times and occupy yourselves within them with acts of obedience and commerce for the Abode of the Hereafter [al-dar al-akhirah]. This is indicated by His saying, the Most High: "And He is the One Who made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember or desires gratitude," meaning one succeeds the other so that what was missed in one may be made up in the other, and He clarified that this is for remembrance [dhikr] and gratitude [shukr], nothing else. Therefore, the path to Allah, the Most High, is the vigilant observance of times [muraqabat al-awqat] and filling them with regular litanies [awrad] in a manner of constancy, and for that reason the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The most beloved of Allah's servants to Allah are those who observe the sun and the moon and the shadows for the remembrance [dhikr] of Allah, the Most High."

And the first thing that is unveiled to him is what harms and benefits him from his good deeds and bad deeds, and that had been inscribed in a book folded in the secret of his heart (Qalb), and the distractions of the world (Dunya) were occupying him from observing it. So when the distractions are cut off, all his actions are unveiled to him, so he does not look at his evil except and regrets it with a regret that makes him prefer to plunge into the depths of the Fire to escape from that regret. And to that servant (Abd) it is said: 'Read your book; sufficient is yourself today as a reckoner against you' (Quran 17:14). And all that is unveiled at the cutting off of the breath (Nafs) and before burial, and the fires of separation ignite in himâ€”meaning separation from what he used to find tranquility in from this perishing world (Dunya), except what he intended from it for the purpose of provision (Zad) and sufficiency (Balgha). For whoever seeks provision for sufficiency, when he reaches the destination, he rejoices at parting with the remainder of the provision, since he did not want the provision for its own sake. Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And among them is extravagance (Israf) in food and building, which is reprehensible (Munkar). Rather, in wealth there are two reprehensible acts: one is waste (Ida'ah) and the other is extravagance (Israf). Waste is squandering wealth without any considered benefit, like burning a garment, tearing it, demolishing a building without purpose, and throwing wealth into the sea. In its meaning is spending wealth on lamentation (Naihah) and entertainment (Mutrib) and in types of corruption, because these are benefits prohibited by law (Sharia), so they become as if non-existent. As for extravagance (Israf), it may be used to intend spending wealth on lamentation (Naihah), entertainment (Mutrib), and reprehensible acts (Munkarat), and it may be used for spending on permissible things (Mubahat) in their kind, but with exaggeration (Mubalaghah). Exaggeration differs relative to circumstances. We say: whoever owns only a hundred dinars, for example, and has his dependents and children with no livelihood except it, and spends all of it on a feast, he is extravagant (Musrif) and must be prevented. Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not extend it all extension, so you sit blamed, exhausted.' This was revealed regarding a man in Medina who distributed all his wealth and left nothing for his dependents, then was demanded for maintenance and could not afford anything. And He said: 'And do not waste wastefully (Tabdhir). Indeed, the wasteful (Mubadhirin) are brothers of the devils.' And likewise, He the Mighty and Glorious said: 'And those who, when they spend, are not extravagant (Yusrifu) and are not stingy (Yaqtiru).' So whoever is extravagant with this extravagance (Israf) is censured, and it is obligatory upon the judge to impose guardianship on him, except if the man is alone and has a true strength in reliance (Tawakkul), then he may spend all his wealth in the paths of good (Abwab al-Birr). And whoever has dependents or is incapable of reliance (Tawakkul) may not give all his wealth in charity. Likewise, if he spends all his wealth on carvings of his walls and adorning his building, that is also prohibited extravagance (Israf Muharram). Doing that by one who has abundant wealth is not prohibited, because adornment is among sound purposes, and mosques have always been adorned and their doors and ceilings carved, even though carving the door and ceiling has no benefit except mere adornment, so likewise houses. And likewise, the statement regarding adornment with clothes and foods: that is permissible (Mubah) in its kind and becomes extravagance (Israf) considering the man's condition and wealth. And examples of these reprehensible acts (Munkarat) are many and cannot be enumerated. So judge by these reprehensible acts (Munkarat) the gatherings, courts of judges, offices of rulers, schools of jurists, retreats of Sufis (Ribatat al-Sufiyyah), and inns of markets. No place is free from a reprehensible (Munkar) disliked or cautioned against. Exhausting all reprehensible acts (Munkarat) requires encompassing all details of the law (Sharia), its principles (Usul) and branches (Furu'), so let us limit to this amount of them. The general reprehensible acts (Munkarat): know that every sitter in his house, wherever he is, is not free.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Sixth: Moderation in expenditure. One should not be stingy with them in spending, nor should one be extravagant, but rather be moderate. Allah the Exalted said: 'And eat and drink, but do not be extravagant' (Quran 7:31). And He said: 'And do not make your hand tied to your neck, nor stretch it out to the utmost extent' (Quran 17:29). And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'The best of you is the best to his family' [127]. And he (peace be upon him) said: 'A dinar you spend in the path of Allah, a dinar you spend to free a slave, a dinar you give in charity to a poor person, and a dinar you spend on your familyâ€”the greatest in reward is the one you spend on your family.' [128]

And Allah the Exalted has praised it, saying: 'And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor stingy, but hold a just balance between that' (Quran 25:67). And He said: 'And do not make your hand chained to your neck nor stretch it out completely' (Quran 17:29). Likewise, the sought-after in the desire for food is moderation without gluttony and abstinence. Allah the Exalted said: 'And eat and drink, but do not be extravagant; indeed, He does not love the extravagant' (Quran 7:31). And He said regarding anger: 'Severe against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves' (Quran 48:29). And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The best of matters are their middle ones.' And this has a secret and verification, which is that happiness is tied to the soundness of the heart from the afflictions of this world. Allah the Exalted said: 'Except he who comes to Allah with a sound heart' (Quran 26:89). And stinginess is from the afflictions of the worldly life, and wastefulness is also from the afflictions of the worldly life, and the condition of the heart is to be sound from both, meaning it should not be attentive to wealth, nor should it be eager to spend it nor to withhold it. For the one eager to spend has his heart diverted to spending, just as the one eager to withhold has his heart diverted to withholding. So the perfection of the heart is to be pure from both descriptions altogether.

We say: For example, one who possesses only one hundred dinars and has dependents and children with no livelihood for them except this, then he spends all of it on a feast - he is wasteful (Musrif) and must be prevented. Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not extend it (your hand) completely extended, so you sit blameworthy, destitute.' This was revealed regarding a man in Al-Madinah who distributed all his wealth and left nothing for his dependents, then was demanded for expenses but was unable to provide anything. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not squander wastefully, indeed the squanderers are brothers of the devils.' And likewise, the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And those who, when they spend, are neither wasteful nor stingy.' So whoever wastes with this wastefulness, it is denounced upon him, and it is obligatory upon the judge to impose guardianship over him, except if the man is alone and has a true strength in Reliance (Tawakkul) upon Allah - then he may spend all his wealth in the paths of righteousness. But whoever has dependents or is incapable of Reliance (Tawakkul) - then it is not for him to give charity with all his wealth.

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And how could one not be held accountable for the works of the Heart (Qalb) from arrogance (Kibr), self-admiration (Ujb), ostentation (Riya), hypocrisy (Nifaq), envy (Hasad), and the entirety of evils from the works of the Heart? Rather, the Hearing (Sam') and the Sight (Basar) and the Heart (Fu'ad) - all of those will be questioned about it, meaning what enters under choice. If the sight falls without choice upon something not forbidden, one is not held accountable for it. But if one follows it with a second look, one is held accountable for it because it is chosen. Likewise, the thoughts of the Heart follow this course. Rather, the Heart is more deserving of being held accountable because it is the origin. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'God-consciousness (Taqwa) is here,' and he pointed to his Heart. And Allah the Exalted said: 'Their flesh and their blood do not reach Allah, but your God-consciousness (Taqwa) reaches Him.' And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Sin is what wavers in the hearts.' And in this station, for the people of stations, there is extravagance and moderation. So whoever is extravagant in elevating appearances ends up changing all appearances and proofs or most of them.

a.g: And when you recite the Qur'an, We put between you and those who do not believe in the Hereafter a concealed partition.
And We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And when you mention your Lord alone in the Qur'an, they turn back in aversion.
We are most knowing of how they listen to it when they listen to you and [of] when they are in private conversation, when the wrongdoers say, "You follow not but a man affected by magic."
Look how they strike for you comparisons; but they have strayed, so they cannot [find] a way.
And they say, "When we are bones and crumbled particles, will we [truly] be resurrected as a new creation?"
Say, "Be you stones or iron

Or [any] creation of that which is great within your breasts." And they will say, "Who will restore us?" Say, "He who brought you forth the first time." Then they will nod their heads toward you and say, "When is that?" Say, "Perhaps it will be soon -
On the Day He will call you and you will respond with praise of Him and think that you had not remained [in the world] except for a little."
And tell My servants to say that which is best. Indeed, Satan induces [dissension] among them. Indeed Satan is ever, to mankind, a clear enemy.

And due to the similarity of the inner insight (Bassira) to the outer insight, Allah the Exalted said: 'The Heart (Fu'ad) did not lie about what it saw' [Quran 53:11], and He said: 'And thus We showed Abraham the dominion (Malakut) of the heavens and the earth' [Quran 6:75] the verse. And He named its opposite blindness, so He said: 'For indeed, it is not the eyes that become blind, but it is the Hearts (Qulub) in the chests that become blind' [Quran 22:46]. And He said: 'And whoever is blind in this [world] will be blind in the Hereafter and more astray in way' [Quran 17:72]. a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
Glory be to the One who made known to His servants what He made known, then addressed them all, saying: *"And you have not been given of knowledge except a little."* This is the clarification of the pivotal points upon which the thoughts of those who contemplate the creation of God, Exalted is He, revolve. And there is in it no contemplation of the Essence [dhat] of God, Exalted is He. But from the contemplation of creation is inevitably gained knowledge [ma'rifa] of the Creator, and His majesty, and His grandeur, and His power. And whenever you increase in knowledge of the wondrous making [sana'] of God, Exalted is He, your knowledge of His grandeur and His majesty becomes more complete. This is just as you hold a scholar in awe due to your knowledge of his knowledge. You do not cease to discover the marvels of his composition or his poetry, so you increase thereby in knowledge, and you increase thereby in reverence, awe, and respect for him, to the point that every word of his words and every wondrous line of his poetry increases his station in your heart [qalb], calling forth awe for him within your soul [nafs]. Thus, contemplate the creation of God, Exalted is He, and His composition and His arrangement, and all that exists of the creation [khalq] of God and His making [tasnif]. And the gazing and the contemplation in it is never-ending. But for every servant [abd] of it is only a portion of what he has been granted. So let us limit ourselves to what we have mentioned, and let us add to this what we have detailed in the Book of Gratitude. For we looked in that book at the act of God, Exalted is He, from the perspective of it being a beneficence to us and a favor upon us. And in this book, we look at it from the perspective that it is solely the act of God. And all that we look upon in itâ€”the naturalist looks upon it and his looking becomes a cause of his misguidance and wretchedness, and the one granted success looks upon it and it becomes a cause of his guidance and his felicity. And there is not a single particle in the heaven and the earth except that God, Glorified and Exalted is He, misguides by it whom He wills and guides by it whom He wills. So whoever looks upon these matters from the perspective that they are the act [fi'l] of God, Exalted is He, and His making [sana'], gains from it knowledge of the majesty of God, Exalted is He, and His grandeur, and is guided by it. And whoever looks upon them, limiting his gaze to them from the perspective of the effect of some of them upon others, and not from the perspective of their connection to the Causer of Causes, has indeed become wretched and has donned the garment of misguidance. So we seek refuge with God from misguidance, and we ask Him to keep us from the stumbling places of the feet of the ignorant, by His grace and His generosity and His bounty and His giving and His mercy.

And the entirety of what they knew is little in addition to what our Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) knew, and what all the Prophets knew is little in addition to what the close Angels (Al-Mala'ikah Al-Muqarrabun) like Israfil and Jibril and others knew. Then all the knowledges of the Angels, the Jinn, and the Humans, when added to the knowledge of Allah (Glory be to Him, the Exalted), do not deserve to be called knowledge; rather, it is closer to being called bewilderment (dahsh), perplexity (hayrah), deficiency (qusur), and incapacity ('ajz). So Glory be to the One who made known to His servants what He made known, then addressed all of them saying: 'And you have not been given of knowledge except a little.' This is an explanation of the nodal points of the sentences in which the thought of the thinkers wanders regarding the creation of Allah (the Exalted), and there is no thought in the Essence (Dhat) of Allah (the Exalted) in them, but from the thought in the creation inevitably comes knowledge of the Creator (Al-Khaliq) and His greatness (azamah), majesty (jalal), and power (qudrah). And whenever you increase in knowledge of the wondrous making (sana') of Allah (the Exalted), your knowledge of His majesty and greatness becomes more complete.

That is their recompense because they disbelieved in Our verses and said, "When we are bones and crumbled particles, will we [truly] be resurrected [in] a new creation?"

Say [to them], "If you possessed the depositories of the mercy of my Lord, then you would withhold out of fear of spending." And ever has man been stingy.

And its perfection is that he says 'Allahu Akbar' and prostrates and supplicates in his prostration with what is appropriate to the verse he recited, such as when he recites the saying of the Exalted: 'They fall down prostrating and glorify with the praise of their Lord and they do not show arrogance' (Quran 38:24), then he says: 'O Allah, make me among those who prostrate to Your Face, those who glorify with Your praise, and I seek refuge in You from being among those who show arrogance against Your command or against Your allies.' And it has been said regarding its perfection that he says 'Allahu Akbar' raising his hands for its prohibition, then he says 'Allahu Akbar' for the inclination to prostration, then he says 'Allahu Akbar' for rising, then he says the salutation. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
Indeed, all of that is praise for fear [khawf], for to censure a thing is to praise its opposite which negates it. And the opposite of fear [khawf] is security [amn], just as the opposite of hope [raja'] is despair [yÄ's]. And just as the censure of despair [qunut] indicates the virtue of hope [raja'], so too does the censure of security [amn] indicate the virtue of the fear [khawf] that opposes it. Rather, I say: Everything that has come regarding the virtue of hope [raja'] is evidence for the virtue of fear [khawf], for they are inseparable [mutalaziman]. For everyone who hopes [yarju] for a beloved [mahbub] must necessarily fear [yakhaf] missing it. If he does not fear [yakhaf] missing it, then he does not love it, and thus he is not hoping [raji] in anticipation of it. Therefore, fear [khawf] and hope [raja'] are inseparable [mutalaziman]; it is impossible for one to be detached from the other. Yes, it is possible for one of them to dominate the other while they are both present, and it is possible for the heart [qalb] to be occupied with one and not turn to the other in a given moment due to heedlessness [ghaflah] of it. This is because a condition of hope [raja'] is fear [khawf]; their connection is to that which is uncertain [mashkuk fih], for what is known [ma'lum] is neither hoped [yurja] for nor feared [yukhaf]. Therefore, the beloved [mahbub] whose existence is possible, its non-existence is also inevitably possible. So, envisioning its existence comforts the heart [qalb], and that is hope [raja']; and envisioning its non-existence pains the heart [qalb], and that is fear [khawf]. And it is inevitable that these two estimations confront each other when that awaited matter is uncertain [mashkuk fih]. Yes, one side of the doubt [shakk] may become preponderant over the other due to the presence of some causes, and that is called assumption [zann], and that becomes a cause for the dominance of one over the other. So, if the assumption [zann] of the beloved's [mahbub] existence dominates, hope [raja'] is strengthened and fear [khawf] becomes hidden relative to it, and likewise the opposite. In any case, they are inseparable [mutalaziman]. And for that reason, the Exalted said: "And they supplicate to Us in eager desire [raghban] and fear [rahaban]" [Qur'an 21:90]. And the Almighty said: "They supplicate to their Lord in fear [khawfan] and hope [tama'an]" [Qur'an 32:16]. And for that reason, the Arabs expressed fear [khawf] as hope [raja']. The Exalted said: "What is [wrong] with you that you do not hope [tarjuna] for Allah grandeur [waqar]?" [Qur'an 71:13] â€“ meaning, you do not fear [takhafuna]. And often in the Qur'an, hope [raja'] has come with the meaning of fear [khawf], due to their inseparability [talazum], for it is the habit of the Arabs to express a thing by what accompanies it. Rather, I say: Everything that has come regarding the virtue of weeping from awe [khashyah] of Allah is a manifestation of the virtue of awe [khashyah], for weeping is the fruit of awe [khashyah]. Indeed, the Exalted said: "So let them laugh a little and weep much" [Qur'an 9:82]. And the Exalted said: "They weep, and it increases them in humility [khushu'an]" [Qur'an 17:109].

Indeed, all praise [al-hamd] is for Allah who has not taken a son. For all praise [al-hamd] for Allah is the extolling of Allah, exalted is He, with what He deserves of attributes of perfection [sifat al-kamal], and the refraining from taking a son indicates His transcendence [tanzih] above deficiency and need. For a son is only taken out of need or for completion, and Allah, exalted is He, is rich [ghani] beyond all worlds. So His praising Himself for that is a clarification of His uniqueness in divinity [uluhiyya] and His freedom from partners. In this is a reminder for the believer that he must be sincere [ikhlas] in his praise of Allah, and that he must bring to mind the meanings of divine oneness [tawhid] in every remembrance [dhikr] and supplication, like the ten words that awaken the heart [qalb] and diversify the remembrance [dhikr] so that it does not grow weary, so that recitation and remembrance become a means to realize this pure praise [hamd khalis].

And we have mentioned that that is disobedience and transgression, not because seeking the worldly life (Dunya) is forbidden, but seeking it through acts of religion is forbidden due to what it contains of showing off (Riya) and changing worship from its proper place. As for the term partnership (Shirkah) where it occurs, it is absolute for equality, and we have clarified that if the two intentions are equal, they cancel each other out, and there is neither for him nor against him, so one should not hope for reward upon it. Then indeed, the human being in partnership is always in danger, for he does not know which of the two matters is more dominant in his intention; perhaps it will be a calamity upon him. And for that reason, Allah the Exalted said: 'So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone' (Quran 18:110), meaning do not hope for the meeting with the partnership whose best state is cancellation.
